Award.AwardTitle: Evolution and development of character displacement
Award.AbstractNarration:
When species compete, they often evolve to become more different in morphological and behavioral features that are important in acquiring vital resources, such as food. This process by which species become more different from a competitor is called "character displacement". Character displacement is critical for explaining how different species can coexist in the same habitat and why even closely related species typically differ. Yet, we know remarkably little about how this process unfolds. The proposed research will fill this critical gap by conducting observations and experiments on natural populations of two species of frogs. This research could prove vital for understanding how living things develop, function, and change over time. Moreover, this work will help us to understand how an organism's environment, not just its genes, affects its development.

Such studies are essential for evaluating the origin and treatment of developmental diseases. This work will also contribute to educational outreach by training young scientists (including K-12 students) in interdisciplinary research, and will broaden access to science by actively recruiting students from underrepresented groups. Finally, because of numerous changes to their environment, many species are currently undergoing radical shifts in their geographical ranges and thereby encountering new competitors. This work could serve as a model for what might happen to biodiversity following such encounters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding how and why living things diversify is a central goal of biology. Ever since Darwin, evolutionary biologists have asserted that competition acts as a ubiquitous and powerful agent of divergent selection. The essence of the idea is that when organisms compete for scarce resources, natural selection should favor those individuals that are least like their competitors. Consequently, individuals, populations, and species that compete should become more dissimilar over time. This evolutionary divergence resulting from selection to lessen competition is termed “character displacement.”

Character displacement is important, because it potentially explains why living things are diverse. Character displacement generates diversity by driving divergence between populations and species, by initiating and finalizing speciation, and by contributing to adaptive radiation (where a single species proliferates into numerous new species that occupy diverse ecological niches). Character displacement also explains species coexistence, and, thus, why species occur where they do. By accentuating differences between species, character displacement reduces competition between them, thereby enabling them to coexist. In sum, character displacement is central in the origins, abundance, and distribution of biodiversity.

This grant examined three, relatively poorly understood aspects of character displacement. First, what evolutionary factors promote character displacement? As it turns out, competitively mediated divergence has been convincingly demonstrated in relatively few studies, and no study has shown this process unfold under controlled, natural conditions. Second, what are the underlying developmental mechanisms and selective targets of character displacement? Although character displacement is typically assumed to reflect selection favoring one set of genetically fixed morphological traits over another, divergence may often arise when selection acts on the ability of individual organisms to respond to changes in their environment by altering their traits; i.e., through “phenotypic plasticity.” Third, what sequence of events leads to character displacement? Character displacement is often assumed to result from an accumulation of genetic differences between species. Alternatively, character displacement may unfold rapidly, as species differences that initially arise through phenotypic plasticity later become genetically fixed.

The grant experimentally evaluated—in a natural setting—the above three issues by using spadefoot toads as a model system. Plains spadefoot toads, Spea bombifrons, and Mexican spadefoot toads, S. multiplicata, co-occur in the southwestern USA. Previous research in the PI’s lab had shown that, in the San Simon Valley of southeastern Arizona, these two species have undergone character displacement with each other. As a manifestation of this character displacement, in allopatry, each species produces similar, intermediate frequencies of two distinct ecomorphs: an omnivore morph, which feeds on detritus, and a carnivore morph, which feeds on fairy shrimp. By contrast, in sympatry, S. multiplicata produce mostly omnivores, whereas S. bombifrons produce mostly carnivores. This divergence between species in ecomorph production has been favored by natural selection, because it reduces competition for food.

The key findings of this grant are that: (i) competitively mediated selection does indeed promote trait divergence between species (i.e., character displacement); (ii) resource-use traits were the targets of this selection; and (iii) character displacement might generally evolve from an initial phase in which trait divergence is environmentally induced to one in which it is expressed constitutively.

In terms of intellectual merit, this grant provided key insights into the causes of character displacement, which is central to the origins, abundance, and distribution of biodiversity. This grant supported the appearance of one book, 42 peer-reviewed publications, and five non-peer-reviewed publications.

In terms of broader impacts, this grant promoted educational outreach by recruiting and training two high school students (one female), six undergraduates (two females, three minorities), and seven Ph.D. students (two females, two Hispanic). Furthermore, the research enhanced public outreach. The PI regularly gives talks to general audiences (e.g., at museums, field stations, and schools), and this research was used to educating the public about how microevolutionary processes that they can observe can generate macroevolutionary patterns of diversity. Finally, because of numerous changes to their environment, many species are currently undergoing radical shifts in their geographical ranges and thereby encountering new competitors. This work could serve as a model for what might happen to biodiversity and patterns of diversification following such encounters.
